column1: Ang Thong (Thai: อ่างทอง
column2: pronounced [ʔàːŋ tʰɔ̄ːŋ]) is one of the central provinces (changwat) of Thailand. The name "Ang Thong" means 'gold basin'
column3: thought to have derived from the basin-like geography of the area
column4: and the golden color of the rice grown in the region.

column1: Neighboring provinces are (from north clockwise) Sing Buri
Ang Thong native handicrafts include moulded court dolls
Ang Thong has more than 200 Buddhist temples
column2: but there are nine distinctive temples that are promoted as "Paying Homage to Nine Auspicious Temples" consists of Wat Chaiyo  Worawihan
column10: Wat Muang where the Great Buddha of Thailand is enshrined.

column1: Ang Thong occupies a low river plain
column2: created by the Chao Phraya and the Noi Rivers. It has neither mountains nor forests
column3: but consists of mostly agricultural land. The two rivers
column5: provide enough water for rice farming.

column1: Ang Thong was historically known as Wiset Chai Chan
column2: on the Noi River. It was an important border town of the Ayutthaya Kingdom during the wars with Burma
column3: as the Noi River served as a natural obstacle for advancing troops.

column1: During the reign of King Taksin after the fall of Ayutthaya
column2: the main city of the province was moved to the Chao Phraya River
column4: as the Noi River had become silted and too shallow for transportation.

column1: Ang Thong is the provenance of Li Ke
column3: and the hometown of Nai Dok and Nai Thongkaeo
column4: two heroes of the Bang Rachan Battle.

column1: Khun Rong Palat Chu is another local hero of Ang Thong. His heroism is little known when compared to the villagers of Bang Rachan because only two lines were recorded in the Thai chronicles. He grouped up and led four hundred volunteer sword fighters under the name "Kong Attamat" to accompany the royal army from the capital during the royal army's settlement at Kui Buri of Prachuap Khiri Khan. His group received a command to obstruct the Burmese army 8
column2: 000 people at Ao Wa Khao (now is in Ao Noi
column3: Mueang Prachuap Khiri Khan) in 1759 when King Alaungpaya of Burma invaded Myeik (Burmese–Siamese War (1759–60)) which was a part of Ayutthaya Kingdom at that time. In the end
column4: they all died of four hundred people. Nowadays
column5: there is a monument built to commemorate his heroism at Wat Si Roi

column1: The provincial seal shows some golden ears of rice in a bowl of water. This symbolizes the fertility of province as one of the major producers of rice. The provincial tree is the gaub tree (Diospyros malabarica). The provincial fish is red tailed tinfoil (Barbonymus altus).
The province is divided into seven districts (amphoes). The districts are further subdivided into 73 subdistricts (tambons) and 513 villages (mubans).

As of 26 November 2019 there are: one Ang Thong Provincial Administration Organisation (ongkan borihan suan changwat) and 21 municipal (thesaban) areas in the province. Ang Thong has town (thesaban mueang) status. Further 20 subdistrict municipalities (thesaban tambon). The non-municipal areas are administered by 43 Subdistrict Administrative Organisations - SAO (ongkan borihan suan tambon).

column2: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in Thailand has tracked progress on human development at sub-national level using the Human achievement index (HAI)
column3: a composite index covering all the eight key areas of human development. National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB) has taken over this task since 2017.
